text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

I'm Paxton Maeder-York, and this
is the new Venture Competition
submission for Alife Health.

Over 180 million families
experience infertility
globally.

This represents a $24
billion international market.

In Vitro Fertilization, or IVF,
is the most common treatment
for infertility.

In the US alone, we've seen
10% year-over-year growth
in IVF procedures.

And this does not
take into account

recent trends of
young women freezing
their eggs for future use.

For a typical patient, IVF
requires tens of thousands

of dollars and several rounds
of therapy to be successful.

The burden of
multiple cycles can

take a financial, physical,
and emotional toll on patients.

One opportunity to reduce
the number of cycles

is through better selection
of which embryo should
be transferred to the mother.

Despite the complexity
and three-dimensionality

of an embryo, for the
majority of patients,

selection today is
performed by an embryologist

looking through a
microscope and comparing it
to a simple diagram.

Recent advances in computer
vision and software algorithms

offer the opportunity for
improved accuracy and higher
chances for a healthy child.

Our team, with backgrounds in
biomedical engineering, data

science, surgical
robotics, and business,

is well poised to
bring this technology
to the benefit of patients.

Your support will
help us as we continue

to work on this important
problem full-time
after graduation.
Thank you very much.
